III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
Section (2) All the following must be in the case record before a youth is
Description placed in independent living:
(f) Proof that financial support to meet the youth's housing,
clothing, food, and miscellaneous expenses is available
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation Two youths were at a community salvation army store begging for
food and water. The youths are not cared for and appeared
dehydrated. The youths alleged the agency has a food pantry, but
it is always empty; they are often hungry, and they have to fend
for themselves.
Investigation Interviews:
Administrator 2
On 10/4/2023, I spoke with the agency’s Quality Director
Administrator 2, whom Chief Administrator 1 had delegated to
follow up with me related to this special investigation.
Administrator 2 reported the agency had just received this
complaint. She confirmed Youth A’s and Youth B’s placement in
the agency’s staffed independent living program; but she was not
sure how long each youth had been with the program. She
reported Quality Manager 3 would assist me related to my
investigation of this complaint.
Complainant X
On 10/5/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X reported she is the case manager at the Salvation
Army located on W. Warren in Dearborn Heights, Michigan. Her
2

department facilitates the church and social services office for
folks needing services. She reported that on Tuesday, 10/3/2023,
around 3:00PM, Youth A and Youth B went into their food pantry.
A Salvation Army staff person saw them and brought them to
Complainant X. Youth A and Youth B asked for food and water.
Both girls “looked badly”, in that they looked hot, exhausted, and
dehydrated. One of the girl’s shirt was sticking to them. When
Complainant X brought out water for them, both girls jumped for
the water. Complainant X acknowledged that 10/3/2023 was a
very hot day; and Youth A and Youth B reported they took the bus
part of the way and had walked part of the way, to get to the
Salvation Army.
Complainant X said Youth A and Youth B told her they lived in an
independent living (IL) foster care program with other youths ages
16 and older, and that they are not treated well, or fed. Youth A
reported being at Vista’s IL program for a while. Youth B reported
being new to the program, having been in other programs and this
one being the worst. Both girls reported Vista’s IL facility has a
food pantry, but it never has food in it. Complainant X asked
Youth A and Youth B whether they had ever spoken with anyone
about not having food, about what they needed, and Youth B,
stated no. Youth B reported that was because it would make their
situation worst if they told. Youth A agreed with Youth B by
commenting ‘Yeah, Yeah” Neither youth reported when they last
ate. They just reported being on their own, and never being fed.
Complainant X reported when people come into their Salvation
Army program with a need, they have the person complete a brief
intake, and application. They conducted such with Youth A and
Youth B. Youth A and Youth B put down the names of four other
youths, who reportedly may need food/services. She said Youth A
and Youth B left with a few can goods and nonperishable items
that they were able to fit into their backpacks. She said she had
offered them a couple of boxes of food, but the girls did not have a
way to carry that much. She reported Youth B had either called
the Vista IL facility or had gotten a call from someone there, and
Youth B had asked for a ride home to carry the food; but they did
not get one. Complainant X overheard a staff (whom, Complainant
X did not know) yell at Youth B and tell the youths they had to get
home by bus.
Complainant X denied Youth A or Youth B ever coming to the
Salvation Arny to ask for food prior to the date she stated. Nor
was she aware of any other youths from Vista Maria’s IL program
coming into the Salvation Army and asking for food.
3

Quality Manager 3
On October 6, I spoke with Quality Manager 3 onsite. She stated
the agency did not become aware of the incident until they
received the complaint. She reported both Youth A and Youth B
are in the agency’s IL Plus program located in their Shepherd Hall
building. She reported each youth in the program receives a
stipend for expenses along with a bridge card to assist them with
food purchases. Case Manager 3 was not sure of the stipend
amounts received by either Youth A or Youth B. She said
Supervisor 4, would know that information.
Youth A
On 10/6/2023 I interviewed Youth A onsite at Shepard Hall. Youth
A reported residing at the Vista Maria IL facility since about
February of 2023. She denied some aspects of this complaint.
She admitted to visiting the Salvation Army and asking for food,
but denied it being because there was no food available for her at
Vista Maria, while simultaneously indicating it was due to that.
She reported she did not have food and so she and Youth B had
planned to visit food pantries. She said she knew she could get
food at the Salvation Army by showing her identification and filling
out an application. She did not disclose how she knew that.
Youth A said she had mentioned to staff about two months ago
that she did not have food, and the staff person (whom she did not
recall), told her to use her bridge card. When I asked her whether
she told a staff person the day she went to the Salvation Army that
she did not have food that day, or whether she had asked them for
food, she had not. Youth A initially stated she asked Supervisor 4
for a $50 Walmart gift card to go get food and Supervisor 4 told
her the agency did not have any more gift cards. Supervisor 4 told
her to call the cafeteria for food. When I clarified with Youth A
whether she told Supervisor 4 that day that she did not have food,
Youth A reported that was two months ago and she was advised
to use her food stamps. Youth A reported the facility has a
cafeteria, which she can get three meals a day, but the problem is
that sometimes the cafeteria is closed. She said the cafeteria is
open from noon to 5pm. When I asked her what she could do for
food if she got hungry before the cafeteria opened or after it
closed, Youth A reported there is a pantry in the building but there
is no real food there. The pantry just has snacks, like, chips, apple
sauce, fruit cups, cereal, Vienna sausages. Also, they can only go
there once per week because there is not enough for everyone.
Youth A admitted all youths do have personal food, it is kept in
4

their personal refrigerator in their room, and in the basement’s
refrigerator with their name on it.
It is noteworthy that right after my interview with Youth A, which
was after 4:00pm, Youth A used her cell phone to call the
cafeteria and place an order for dinner.
Youth A reported being a full-time student. She said she receives
an IL stipend check of $350 every two weeks; and she receives
$108 in food stamps. She said the agency charges her $208 every
two weeks for rent ($416). She said $700 is not enough to pay
her bills, which also includes $127 monthly cell phone and private
Wi-Fi payment. She admitted the agency staff takes them
grocery shopping monthly or as needed. She reported knowing
this is an IL program but that it is hard trying to do everything on
her own, especially since she does not have a job. She reported
since it’s an IL program they do not have to tell the staff exactly
where they are going, but they do have to sign in and out of the
building. She said the day she and Youth B visited the Salvation
Army she did not sign out for the Salvation Army. The staff did
not know where she was going or why.
On 10/6/2023 Youth A left the building for the weekend before I
could view her room or personal refrigerator.
Supervisor 4
On 10/6/2023 I interviewed Supervisor 4 onsite at Shepard Hall. I
also spoke with her briefly on 10/25/2023 onsite prior to me
interviewing Youth B. Supervisor 4 reported employment with the
agency for two years. She supervises the IL workers and IL
coaches. She denied the allegation of there not being any food
for youths at the facility, or Youth A and Youth B having to fend for
themselves. She reported that Youth A has been in the agency’s
IL program since March 2023 and Youth B since 8/16/2023. She
reported that neither youth has been without access to food/a
meal or assistance. Nor had either of the girls reported they were
going to pick up food because they had none or were hunger.
Neither reported where they were going that day, because it’s not
required that they report where they are going. They do have to
sign out and be back before curfew. The day of the incident Youth
A and Youth B signed out at 2:13pm and returned at 7:23PM.
Supervisor 4 also affirmed aspects of Youth A’s reporting related
to Youth A and other youths in the program receiving a stipend of
$700 or a little more than that monthly. Additionally, of there being
a cafeteria onsite where youths can obtain, breakfast, lunch and
5

dinner meals, by calling their meal into that cafeteria, if the youth
so chooses. Supervisor 4 said the youth just has to pick up a
dinner meal before 5:00pm or have a staff pick it up for them. She
said all youths’ rent, is only $208 monthly; and some youths
including Youth A and Youth B often do not pay that. She
reported that Youth A receives foods stamps, but Youth B
procrastinated with completion of her application for a bridge card.
Youth B has only recently applied for assistance. She reported
any other expenses for the youths is typically just a cell phone;
and the rest of their money is for any other expenses they select.
She said despite staff’s attempts to budget with the youths, Youth
A tends to waste her funds. She explained that about two weeks
ago, Youth A received/won $2700 via some type of MARE
(Michigan Adoption Resource Exchange) drawing. Youth A was
advised to buy food to store and to put the bulk of the funds in the
bank. Youth A did not. Youth A spent all the money. Youth A
purchased clothing, inclusive of a full Lion’s jogging suit, gym
shoes, an X box and other items. Supervisor B said Youth B
spends her money in other not always responsible ways; inclusive
of paying money for transports to go visit Youth B’s boyfriend. She
said both Youth A and Youth B know her, her level of authority in
the IL program, and neither youth came to her that day to report a
concern. Also, neither of the youth reported they did not have
food. If they had reported this, arranging for food for them would
not have been a problem. Supervisor 4 reported, it was brought to
her attention after the fact, by Youth C that Youth A had reported
Youth A planned to set up Supervisor 4, so as to get the IL
program shut down some way.
Supervisor 4 further reported that every Friday an IL staff
transports the IL youths to grocery shop, if the youth wants to go.
She said Youth A has participated in grocery shopping a few
times, but often Youth A, as well as many other youths sometime
choose to go to a restaurant or utilize door dash to order meals.
Supervisor 4 said all the youths have a mini refrigerator and
microwave in their room. Should a youth have a large supply of
food items, the youth can store items in either the upstairs’
refrigerator, or the one in the basement where there is also a full
kitchen. Supervisor 4 added, the agency also sometimes uses gift
cards to purchase a meal so that the girls do not have to use their
food stamps, and the staff can utilize that time to teach the youths
a skill. She said the agency also stocks food, which is “community
food” in the refrigerator or freezer where food is always located. If
a youth does not have food they can get food from there. Or the
youth can access “dry foods”, cracker, chips, noodles, nutritional
6

bars, etc. from the food pantry which always contains some type
of items.
Youth B
On 10/25/2023 I interviewed Youth B onsite at Shepard Hall. I
read her the allegations and she reported the allegations as
reported were not correct. She reported it was true she and Youth
A visited the Salvation Army, but that she had never reported that
she was starving. She also denied telling anyone at the Salvation
Army that Vista Maria’s IL’s program was the worst place she had
ever been in. She said she thought she was going to a thrift shop
with her friend. She admitted not receiving food stamps back
then, but reported it was not true that there was not food available
for her at Vista Maria. She reported the IL staff had offered to
assist her in applying for a bridge card, but it was her who had not
followed through, something she reported doing last week. She
reported it is not the staff’s job to feed her, but they should know
when a youth is in need. She said, the IL program has gift cards
which it gives to youths for things they need; but the staff believes
the youth should have a plan for how it will be spent, and youths
can only get a gift card once every two weeks. She admitted she
can receive meals from the cafeteria, but said she chooses not to,
because she does not like the food. She reported the food makes
her sick due to her acid reflux disorder. As to the IL program
having a pantry and refrigerators with food that she and other
youths can store food in, and access food items if they do not
have food, Youth B said those storages don’t always stay stocked;
but as long as food is there, she can use it. She further admitted
to going grocery shopping with staff on Fridays, receiving an IL
stipend from the state every two weeks, and being able to buy
food. She said, however, her finances have been “messed up”
lately, meaning they have been low; but she did not say why her
finances have been low. Her stipend is $358 every two weeks,
and she paid $208, monthly for rent, and $81 monthly for another
expense which she did not elaborate on.
After my interview with Youth B, she showed me her room and
refrigerator, which contained a few food items.
Youth Interviews
On 10/6/2023, I interviewed Youth C, Youth D onsite. I also
attempted to interview Youth E, but Youth E refused to be
interviewed. Youth C and Youth D affirmed youths receiving a
stipend from the government and a bridge card, which staff help
them to apply for when they first arrive. Additionally, them having
a microwave and mini fridge in their rooms, being able to receive
7

meal tickets for food from the cafeteria, having access to the food
pantry, and or them receiving gift cards if they run out of food.
Youth C also reported that Youth A’s and Youth B’s trip to the
Salvation Army was some type of plot. That Youth A and Youth B
said they were going to go the different childcare places and
centers to try and get Vista Maria shut down. Youth C said Youth
B was upset with staff over an incident of a knife being taking from
her, and Youth B and Youth A wanted some staff to get in trouble.
Youth C reported that unless Youth A and Youth B had eaten all
their food, which they did not believe then Youth A and Youth B
had food. Youth C reported not hanging out with Youth A and
Youth B, to be certain of the latter, and indicated Youth E might
know more specifics.
Youth D also reported further information. She reported the IL
pantry may get low, but it is never empty. She said they shop to
restock the pantry every month; and the staff gets the IL youths
input on what the youths want to have in the pantry. Youth D said
they do have to ask to take things out the pantry, but that is so
that staff can write it down and know how to refill it. She said, they
do not have to ask for things out the community freezer and
refrigerator, they can just use what they need/want. She said the
staff refill the community freezer and refrigerator regularly and
takes youths shopping with their bridge card every other Friday.
Youth D said youths can also go shopping on their own, because
“It is an independent living program.”
Staff Interviews
On 10/6/2023 I interviewed IL Staff 5, Staff 6, and Staff 7. Staff 6
reported being off the day of this incident and having no
knowledge of Youth A’s and Youth B’s Salvation Army visit. Staff
5, and Staff 7 reported not knowing Youth A and Youth B visited
that center until after the fact. All the staff reported not knowing
that one could obtain food via the Salvation Army and were
surprise the youths had tried to do this.
All three of the staff confirmed information as reported by
Supervisor 4, and others related to youths receiving stipends,
bridge cards, and Youth A, Youth B and all the youths having
access to food. Staff 5 and Staff 6 denied that Youth A or Youth B
reported to them that they were hungry or without food. Staff 7
said Youth A is always saying she ran out of food, and she directs
Youth A to the food pantry, community refrigerator and cafeteria.
Staff 7 also confirmed Supervisor 4’s reporting of Youth A
8

receiving $2700 and wasting it on Lions’ gear and electronics
instead of essential items or saving it.
Tour Observation:
During my onsite visits I viewed the upstairs and downstairs
refrigerators, as well as the freezer and the pantry which showed
limited food items in all on 10/6/2023, but more food items on
10/25/2023, where meats, hotdogs, milk, bread, potatoes tots,
chicken, frozen vegetables, egg rolls, were seen; and more
nonperishable items were in the pantry such as pop tarts, noodles,
water, juice, apple sauce, peanut butter crackers, nutritional bars,
etc. on the latter date. The agency’s cafeteria was viewed to have
a full commercial kitchen where food is able to be prepared for
children and youths in the Vista Maria campus programs, inclusive
of its IL program. Also viewed was the current weeks menu that
showed a full meal for breakfast, lunch and dinner.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A’s and Youth B’s case records showed:
➢ Youth A and Youth B signed an IL contract for entry
into the Vista Maria IL program.
➢ Youth A is an MCI ward who entered Vista Maria’s IL
program on 3/21/2023.
➢ Youth A’s monthly stipend is documented as $714,
food stamps are $108 monthly. Youth A’s monthly
expenses are rent for $208 monthly. Her last budget
was completed 8/14/2023.
➢ Youth A has AWOLed from the IL program a number
of times since her initial placement.
➢ Youth B is a temporary court ward, who entered the
Vista Maria IL program on 8/16/2023.
➢ Youth B’s monthly stipend and rent is the same as
Youth A’s.
Analysis Based on interviews, observations, and review of documents there
is not evidence to support the allegations of the youths not having
access to food, food not being available to youths when needed,
or a lack of financial support to meet the youth’s housing, clothing,
food, and other needs.
Conclusion Violation Not Established.
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry.
Description (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and suitable
and able to meet the needs of children and families served by the
agency.
9

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The staff are mean and rude to the youths. The youths called the
shelter for a ride back to the facility and staff told them to get
home on their own.
Investigation Interviews:
Administrator 2
On 10/4/2023, I spoke with the agency’s Quality Director
Administrator 2, related to this complaint. She confirmed Youth A’s
and Youth B’s placement in the agency’s staffed independent
living program. She was not aware of any details related to this
complaint; and reported Quality Manager 3 would follow up and
assist me on this matter.
Complainant X
On 10/5/2023 I interviewed Complainant X by telephone.
Complainant X reported while Youth A and Youth B were at the
Salvation Army the girls reported the IL facility’s staff do not treat
them well; that the staff are mean and rude to them. Complainant
X acknowledged that neither youth defined what being mean or
rude to them meant or entailed. Nor did the girls name the staff
who treated them that way. Complainant X reported she
witnessed such behavior by a staff person from the IL facility
during a telephone call Youth B had with a staff person.
Complainant X said a person from the IL facility called Youth B,
and Youth B put the call on speaker. Complainant X reported
hearing the staff questioning Youth B about Youth B’s and Youth
A’s whereabouts. As Youth B tried to explain that she and Youth
A were getting food, the staff person began yelling at Youth B,
telling Youth B she has a meeting coming up that she would have
to attend and she and Youth A needed to get home on their own
either by walking or by bus.
Youth A
On 10/6/2023 I interviewed Youth A onsite at Shepard Hall. Youth
A reported to get along “okay” with the “upstairs staff” but not so
well with all the “downstairs staff”. She reported the latter is
because “they yell at me, and just look at me crazy”. Youth A
admitted all the staff do not yell at her or look at her crazy. She
reported Staff 8 looks at her crazy, and she overheard that staff
talking about her. The staff was telling someone in the office that
Youth A does not belong there. Youth A said Staff 6 yells at her.
Youth A’s example of when this yelling occurred, was related to
Youth A burning a candle in her room. Youth A said Staff 6 yelled
and cursed at her about the incident, took her candle; and would
not listen to the fact that the candle was her personal item and
10

part of her religion. Youth A denied speaking with Supervisor 4
about the staff persons’ behavior, but she may have spoken with
her peer support worker, Staff 5, about the incident. With the
exception of Youth B, Youth A denied any other youth witnessing
Staff 6 yelling and cursing at her. Youth A reported no problems
or concerns with any other staff.
Supervisor 4
On 10/6/2023 I interviewed Supervisor 4 onsite at Shepard Hall.
Supervisor 4 denied the allegations, but admitted she was the one
to call Youth B about a meeting that Youth B was due at
pertaining to an upcoming court hearing. Supervisor 4 denied her
voice being raised or her yelling during the call. She said when
Youth B said she was at the Salvation Army, she assumed Youth
A was getting clothes. When Youth B asked her whether she
could come pick her and Youth A up, Supervisor 4 told Youth B,
no, that the meeting was happening now; and Supervisor 4
immediately put Youth B on speaker, connecting them with the
department worker and others. Supervisor 4 reported after the
meeting Youth B did not ask her to come pick her up, nor did she
tell Youth B to get home the best way she could. They just ended
the call by hanging up.
As for Youth A or Youth B reporting any staff mistreating them or
yelling and cursing them; Youth B has not reported anything.
Youth A recently reported that Staff 6 yelled and cursed her about
a candle. Supervisor 4 said she spoke with Staff 6 about the
matter and Staff 6 denied yelling or cursing Youth A. Staff 6
explained that while completed nightly security checks, Staff 6
observed Youth A burning a candle in her room; and Staff 6
removed the candle due to safety concerns. Supervisor 4
reported following up with Youth A and advising Youth A to use a
flameless candle to do her Tarot Cards, which Youth A reported is
a part of her religion.
Supervisor 4 also reported last night Youth A texted her to say “I
better get my staff” referring to Staff 6 and Staff 8, that those staff
persons look at her crazy and that makes her feel uncomfortable.
Supervisor 4 reported she will be following up with all about this
matter. Supervisor 4 denied any other youths reporting or
complaining to her about Staff 6 and Staff 8 or that any staff was
yelling and cursing them. She said the only thing the youths
complain about is Staff 6 getting into their business; something
Supervisor 4 explains happens by the mere fact that Staff 6 is an
afternoon staff who has more interaction with the youths, tries to
11

engage them, and is asking them questions. Staff 8 is a midnight
staff, and the youths have limited personal interaction with her.
Youth B
On 10/25/2023 I interviewed Youth B onsite at Shepard Hall.
She reported some staff need to work more to decrease issues
that come up with the youths, but she denied there being staff she
does not get along with. She reported at times there are staff and
people she has issues with, but no staff persons are disrespecting
her or mistreating her. As for a staff person yelling at her the day
she was at the Salvation Army, Youth B admitting she was to have
a court hearing, had forgotten about it and Supervisor 4 called and
reminded her of that. Supervisor 4 was upset that she was not at
the facility and let that be known, but Supervisor 4 was not mean
to her and they were told to get back to the facility on their own.
Youth B said she and Youth B had gotten to the Salvation Army
on their own, so that was not a problem.
Youth B acknowledged an awareness of Youth A having a burning
candle in her room, which is not allowed, but she did not report
hearing any staff yelling at Youth A.
Youth Interviews
On 10/6/2023, I interviewed Youth C, and Youth D onsite. I also
attempted to interview Youth E, but Youth E refused to be
interviewed. Youth C and Youth D reported that staff treat them
well. Both youths denied being mistreated, yelled at or cursed.
Aside from Youth D reporting that some youths say Staff 6 will nag
at them to do things, both Youth C and Youth D deny observing
any staff be mean to or mistreat any of the youths.
Staff Interviews
On 10/6/2023 I interviewed Staff 5, Staff 6, and Staff 7.
Staff 5 is the IL specialist for both Youth A and Youth B. She
reported on 10/3/2023 around 3:30pm she was on the call when
Supervisor 4 called Youth B for a virtual meeting. Supervisor 4
never yelled at Youth A. As for Youth A and or Youth B coming
to her to report or complain about any staff being mean, rude or
yelling and cursing them, Staff 5 said Youth A texted her this
morning saying that “I need to check my staff”. Youth A indicated
that Staff 6 and Staff 8 were being rude and mean to her by
looking at her crazy. Staff 5 said she spoke with Youth A today
about Youth A’s concerns. Youth A said she ignores those staff
when they talk to her because they make her feel uncomfortable,
because she thinks they are talking about her. Staff 5 said she
12

also shared the information with Supervisor 4. Staff 5 further
reported that Youth A is constantly trying different things to get out
of the program, though she could not say for certain this complaint
by Youth A is a part of that.
As to whether any other youths have complained or expressed
concerns about staff members mistreating them, Staff 5 reported
that other than some youths reporting, in general, that some staff
are rude, without them giving any specific information about that
or examples, she had not received any complaints about staff
mistreatment.
Staff 6 denied the allegation of her being mean and rude to
youths or her yelling or cursing Youth A or any youth. She
admitted her supervisor has spoken with her twice about a youth’s
complaint of her being mean to them, but she denied it being true.
She said there was one incident with a youth who is no longer at
facility, and one related to Youth A. In the first incident. Staff 6
reported she had asked the youth to do her chores and the youth
yelled and cursed her and then reported the opposite. In that
incident another staff was present and confirmed that. In the
incident with Youth A, she had discovered Youth A to be burning a
candle in Youth A’s room and she had to retrieve the object and
Youth B got upset about it and yelled at her.
She reported that as long as the youths are getting their way with
staff there are no problems, but if the youth is being told to follow
rules or do something they do not like, the youth thinks staff are
being mean. Staff 6 reported she does not curse or yell at any
